summary: FBI 302 report documenting an interview with a Bureau of Prisons Lieutenant regarding his duties at the Manhattan Correctional Center and his involvement in the cellmate assignment for Jeffrey Epstein prior to Epstein's death. The interview covers standard procedures, training, and specific events leading up to Epstein being left without a cellmate.

persons.name: Kerry Calnan
persons.context: FBI Special Agent present for the interview of the BOP Lieutenant, and the drafter of the FD-302 report.

persons.name: David Carpenter
persons.role: Office of the Inspector General Special Agent
persons.context: OIG Special Agent present for the interview of the BOP Lieutenant.

persons.name: Rebekah Donaleski
persons.context: AUSA present for the interview of the BOP Lieutenant at the SDNY USAO.

persons.name: Nicolas Roos
persons.context: AUSA present for the interview; his email regarding cellmate assignment was shown to the BOP Lieutenant during the interview.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate at MCC who was placed on suicide watch, assigned a cellmate, and later found dead. The interview focuses on procedures surrounding his custody.

persons.name: Reyes
persons.context: Inmate initially assigned to be Jeffrey Epstein's cellmate in the SHU. He was later removed from Epstein's cell for a court appearance and released from MCC.

persons.name: Darden
persons.context: A Captain at MCC. The BOP Lieutenant stated he did not inform Captain Darden that inmate Reyes had been released and Epstein was without a cellmate.

connections.description: SA Calnan was one of the law enforcement officials who interviewed the BOP Lieutenant regarding Epstein's incarceration.
AUSA Roos was present for the interview and had previously sent an email to the Lieutenant regarding cellmate assignment procedures.
The BOP Lieutenant was involved in operations in the SHU where Epstein was held and was responsible for placing his initial cellmate.
Inmate Reyes was selected and placed as Jeffrey Epstein's cellmate while Epstein was on suicide watch.
The BOP Lieutenant reported to Captain Darden but failed to inform him of a key change in Epstein's cellmate status.

events.title: Epstein's Cellmate Released
events.description: Inmate Reyes, who was cellmates with Jeffrey Epstein, was removed from the cell for a court appearance and subsequently released from MCC. Epstein was left without a cellmate.

events.title: Epstein's Death Reported
events.description: The BOP Lieutenant, who was not working that day, heard about Jeffrey Epstein's death via news reports.

events.title: Interview of BOP Lieutenant
events.description: FBI and OIG agents, along with AUSAs, interviewed a BOP Lieutenant at the SDNY USAO regarding procedures and events at MCC leading up to Epstein's death.

locations: United States Attorney's Office (SDNY), 1 Saint Andrews Plaza, New York, NY
Manhattan Correctional Center (MCC), 150 Park Row, New York, NY
keyFacts: A BOP Lieutenant was interviewed about MCC procedures and confirmed that Jeffrey Epstein was placed on suicide watch and initially given a cellmate (inmate Reyes).
On August 9, 2019, inmate Reyes was released from MCC after a court appearance, leaving Epstein without a cellmate. The Lieutenant did not inform the relieving shift or Captain Darden of this change.
Standard MCC procedure for inmates on suicide watch was to assign them a cellmate, as indicated by a 'hot list' from the psychology unit.
The Lieutenant recalled receiving an email from AUSA Nicolas Roos prior to assigning Reyes as Epstein's cellmate, indicating some level of external awareness or direction regarding the arrangement.
The tenth floor of MCC, where the SHU was located, was described as not a full floor, similar to an attic, with access controlled and separate from elevator service to other floors.
